crender 0.7.2.9000

    crender: Conditional rendering for Rmarkdown

    crender.Rmd

    One of the main uses of crender is to generate multiple documents with different content from the same RMarkdown.

    The easiest way to start with crender is by installing the Rmdx package where you will find a preconfigured template with the necessary settings to use crender, and basic explanations of how continue.

    However, this is not the only way to use crender and below we also show instructions on how to start and get the most out of crender.

    First you must specify the desired formats in the output argument in the yaml of your RMarkdown document. For this it is important that you take into account the considerations made in the section of Supported formats.

    ---
title: "Template Title"
author: "Daniel E. de la Rosa"
date: "2021-03-04"
output: 
  ioslides_presentation: default
  Rmdx::rmdx_pdf: default
  Rmdx::rmdx_html:
    footer_name: 'Daniel E. de la Rosa'
params:
  html: yes
  ioslides: no
  latex: no
---

    Likewise, in the parameters (params) you must specify keywords as formats, with their respective truth value. Where:

    • TRUE, true, yes: indicates if the content should be inserted by default in the document in question.
    • FALSE, false, no: indicates whether the content not should be inserted by default in the document in question.

    Once this is done, you just have to load the crender library and start using it. In this sense, the cr_val () function will be very useful.

    library(crender)
knitr::opts_chunk$set(echo = cr_val(), include = cr_val(), comment = "")

    With the above instructions, crender is telling knitr that the code chunks and their results will only be inserted in the formats specified as yes in the params.

    To insert non-code content, such as plain text or markdown, you can use the cr_content () function, where you can also insert simple R code evaluations. For the latter, the R code must be surrounded by curly braces, Ex: {sum (1: 4)} or {mean(cars$dist)}.

    The double conditional or cr2 is an argument present in the crender functions with which the default result for a specific format can be negated, in a specific code evaluation. Resulting in the possibility of inserting content that in principle was not supposed to be included in said format. You can double condition as many formats as you want.

    The exclusive content or only is an argument present in the crender functions with which, in a specific code evaluation, the value is made false for all formats except the one specified in the argument. With this you can include content in a specific format regardless of its initial configuration.

    Take a look at this document for specific examples of how to use these functions.

    crender in action

    Make sure you have crender installed.

    If you donâ€™t have the Rmdx library installed, download the two files available at this address, and replace the yaml with this:

    ---
title: "Template Title"
author: "Daniel E. de la Rosa"
date: "marzo 04, 2021"
output: 
  ioslides_presentation: default
  pdf_document: default
  html_document: default
params:
  html: yes
  ioslides: no
  latex: no
---

    If you install Rmdx just create a new Rmarkdown document from the Rmdx crender template.

    Read the contents of the .Rmd file and knit it for each of the specified formats. Then compare the content of this with the results of each knit.

    The file generates three different documents:

    • An html with interactive content and so on.
    • A pdf (latex) with more summarized and formal content.
    • A presentation in ioslides with fairly summarized information for presentation purposes.

    Each of these documents has its own structure but they share some elements, such as the fact that the processing occurs only once and is shared among all, which means that if you make a change in any calculation or formula, you will see reflected in all related documents immediately.

    Supported formats

    Below is a table showing the RMarkdown package formats supported by crender.

    Package Function Keyword Format
    Rmarkdown html_document html html
    html_notebook
    slidy_presentation slidy
    ioslides_presentation ioslides
    word_document docx docx
    latex_document latex tex
    pdf_document pdf
    beamer_presentation beamer
    github_document github md
    md_document markdown_strict
    odt_document odt odt
    powerpoint_presentation pptx pptx
    rtf_document rtf rtf

    • Note that the functions shared by the same keyword cannot be differentiated in render, so it is not recommended to work with several of them at the same time, or the results may differ from what is expected.

    • Likewise, you must take into account that the functions that share the same format are going to overwrite each other. That is, although they can be used together, it is important to rename the output before knitr another of the functions that share format.

    In theory, crender can be used with any RMarkdown format. To do this, along with the previous observations, it must be taken into account that the keyword used must coincide with one of the formats supported by pandoc or be identifiable in the path of the template used.

    In this sense, any of the formats provided in the package xaringan, for example, could be used with the keyword xaringan, although obviously we would consider that the output format is .html so the previous observation in this regard should be taken into account.
